name: Ada Yonath
description: For studies of the structure and function of the ribosome

name: Alice Munro
description: Master of the contemporary short story

name: Alva Myrdal
description: Former Cabinet Minister; Diplomat; Writer.

name: Aung San Suu Kyi
description: For her non-violent struggle for democracy and human rights

name: Barbara McClintock
description: For her discovery of mobile genetic elements

name: Bertha von Suttner
description: Honorary President of Permanent International Peace Bureau, Bern, Switzerland; Author of "Lay Down Your Arms".

name: Betty Williams
description: Founder of the Northern Ireland Peace Movement (later renamed Community of Peace People)

name: Carol W. Greider
description: For the discovery of how chromosomes are protected by telomeres and the enzyme telomerase

name: Christiane Nüsslein-Volhard
description: For their discoveries concerning the genetic control of early embryonic development

name: Donna Strickland
description: For their method of generating high-intensity, ultra-short optical pulses

name: Doris Lessing
description: That epicist of the female experience, who with scepticism, fire and visionary power has subjected a divided civilisation to scrutiny

name: Dorothy Hodgkin
description: For her determinations by X-ray techniques of the structures of important biochemical substances

name: Elfriede Jelinek
description: For her musical flow of voices and counter-voices in novels and plays that with extraordinary linguistic zeal reveal the absurdity of society's clichés and their subjugating power

name: Elinor Ostrom
description: For her analysis of economic governance, especially the commons

name: Elizabeth Blackburn
description: For the discovery of how chromosomes are protected by telomeres and the enzyme telomerase

name: Ellen Johnson Sirleaf
description: For their non-violent struggle for the safety of women and for women's rights to full participation in peace-building work

name: Emily Greene Balch
description: Formerly Professor of History and Sociology; Honorary International President, Women's International League for Peace and Freedom.

name: Esther Duflo
description: For their experimental approach to alleviating global poverty

name: Frances H. Arnold
description: For the directed evolution of enzymes

name: Françoise Barré-Sinoussi
description: For their discovery of HIV, human immunodeficiency virus

name: Gabriela Mistral
description: For her lyric poetry which, inspired by powerful emotions, has made her name a symbol of the idealistic aspirations of the entire Latin American world

name: Gertrude B. Elion
description: For their discoveries of important principles for drug treatment

name: Gerty Cori
description: For their discovery of the course of the catalytic conversion of glycogen

name: Grazia Deledda
description: For her idealistically inspired writings which with plastic clarity picture the life on her native island and with depth and sympathy deal with human problems in general

name: Herta Müller
description: Who, with the concentration of poetry and the frankness of prose, depicts the landscape of the dispossessed

name: Irène Joliot-Curie
description: For their synthesis of new radioactive elements

name: Jane Addams
description: Sociologist; International President, Women's International League for Peace and Freedom.

name: Jody Williams
description: For their work for the banning and clearing of anti-personnel mines

name: Leymah Gbowee
description: For their non-violent struggle for the safety of women and for women's rights to full participation in peace-building work

name: Linda B. Buck
description: For their discoveries of odorant receptors and the organization of the olfactory system

name: Mairead Maguire
description: Founder of the Northern Ireland Peace Movement (later renamed Community of Peace People)

name: Malala Yousafzai
description: For their struggle against the suppression of children and young people and for the right of all children to education".

name: Maria Goeppert-Mayer
description: For their discoveries concerning nuclear shell structure

name: Marie Skłodowska-Curie
description: In recognition of the extraordinary services they have rendered by their joint researches on the radiation phenomena discovered by Professor Henri Becquerel

name: Marie Skłodowska-Curie
description: For her discovery of radium and polonium

name: May-Britt Moser
description: For their discoveries of cells that constitute a positioning system in the brain

name: Mother Teresa
description: Leader of Missionaries of Charity, Calcutta.

name: Nadia Murad
description: For their efforts to end the use of sexual violence as a weapon of war and armed conflict

name: Nadine Gordimer
description: Who through her magnificent epic writing has - in the words of Alfred Nobel - been of very great benefit to humanity

name: Nelly Sachs
description: For her outstanding lyrical and dramatic writing, which interprets Israel's destiny with touching strength

name: Olga Tokarczuk
description: “For a narrative imagination that with encyclopedic passion represents the crossing of boundaries as a form of life”

name: Pearl S. Buck
description: For her rich and truly epic descriptions of peasant life in China and for her biographical masterpieces

name: Rigoberta Menchú
description: In recognition of her work for social justice and ethno-cultural reconciliation based on respect for the rights of indigenous peoples

name: Rita Levi-Montalcini
description: For their discoveries of growth factors

name: Rosalyn Sussman Yalow
description: For the development of radioimmunoassays of peptide hormones

name: Selma Lagerlöf
description: In appreciation of the lofty idealism, vivid imagination and spiritual perception that characterize her writings

name: Shirin Ebadi
description: For her efforts for democracy and human rights. She has focused especially on the struggle for the rights of women and children

name: Sigrid Undset
description: Principally for her powerful descriptions of Northern life during the Middle Ages

name: Svetlana Alexievich
description: For her polyphonic writings, a monument to suffering and courage in our time

name: Tawakkol Karman
description: For their non-violent struggle for the safety of women and for women's rights to full participation in peace-building work

name: Toni Morrison
description: Who in novels characterized by visionary force and poetic import, gives life to an essential aspect of American reality

name: Tu Youyou
description: For her discoveries concerning a novel therapy against Malaria (artemisinin)

name: Wangari Maathai
description: For her contribution to sustainable development, democracy and peace

name: Wisława Szymborska
description: For poetry that with ironic precision allows the historical and biological context to come to light in fragments of human reality
